ground_truth: He leans over and kisses her. Mickey, his hands in his pockets, walks along the sidewalk, one person among many other pedestrians. He pulls his coat tighter around him as he walks. He glances inside and sees Holly, her jacket flung over her shoulders, looking at some records. Mickey walks through the revolving doors of Tower Records, up a few stairs to the selling floor proper, and stops right in front of Holly. Holly chuckles and turns to look at more records. She walks down the aisle, occasionally glancing at the bins of records. Mickey walks beside her. Mickey walks back onscreen to Holly. The two of them are partially obscured by a large white Jazz sign imprinted with a large red circle as they continue their conversation. Mickey pulls out a record and looks at it. Holly looks hopefully at Mickey. Holly laughs, embarrassed, as Mickey puts the record he's been looking at back in the bin. Holly chuckles, looking off for a moment. There is a brief pause and the movie cuts to the screen showing a chaise in Mickey's apartment; an ashtray on a stand sits nearby. The camera moves down the chaise, past several piles of books, to Mickey's coffee table. He sits, picking at his fingers and listening, on the edge of the table in front of Holly, who is sitting cross-legged on the floor, propped up with a pillow, reading her script aloud. Holly closes the script and looks up at Mickey. Mickey smiles and shrugs, not knowing what to say. Holly, thrilled with Mickey's overwhelming response, stands up, her hand on her head. Unable to contain herself, she begins to walk up and down the room, holding her script. The camera follows her; Mickey is now offscreen. Trees line the sidewalk. Holly and Mickey emerge from the door and walk up the street, revealing a whole row of similar apartment buildings. They pass a few other people as they walk. The film then moves to the outside of a charming glass and stained wood café. Through the window, Holly and Mickey can be seen having lunch. Holly is talking animatedly; Mickey takes a sip of coffee. Some people pass by. Next, the film cuts to an almost isolated path in Central Park, complete with old-fashioned streetlamps and scattered leaves. Holly and Mickey stroll into view, deep in conversation. The film abruptly cuts to Mickey's flashback, a visual counterpoint to the story he is telling Holly. A close-up of a nervous, perspiring, and panting Mickey alone in his apartment appears on the screen as his voice is heard. Mickey raises the barrel of a rifle to his forehead. He shuts his eyes tightly. The camera moves past the desperate Mickey to a mirror on the wall behind him.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution

He pulls his coat tighter around him as he strides. He glances inside and notices Holly, her jacket tossed over her shoulders, examining some records. Unable to contain herself, she begins to pace the room, holding her script. The camera follows her; Mickey is now offscreen. Trees line the pavement. Holly and Mickey emerge from the door and walk up the street, revealing a whole row of similar apartment buildings. They pass a few other individuals as they walk. The film then moves to the outside of a charming glass and stained wood café. Through the window, Holly and Mickey can be seen having lunch. Holly is talking animatedly; Mickey takes a sip of coffee. Holly and Mickey stroll into view, deep in conversation. The film abruptly cuts to Mickey's flashback, a visual counterpoint to the story he is telling Holly. A close-up of a nervous, perspiring, and panting Mickey alone in his apartment appears on the screen as his voice is heard. Mickey raises the barrel of a rifle to his forehead. He shuts his eyes tightly. The camera moves past the desperate Mickey to a mirror on the wall behind him.

Holly, thrilled with Mickey's overwhelming response, stands up, her hand is on her head. Unable to contain herself, she begins to walk up and down the room, holding her script. The camera follows her; Mickey is now offscreen. The sidewalk is lined by trees. Holly and Mickey emerge from the door and walk up the street, revealing a whole row of similar apartment buildings. test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: He leans over and kisses her. Mickey, hands in pockets, walks along the sidewalk among other pedestrians, pulling his coat tighter. He glances inside and sees Holly, jacket draped over her shoulders, browsing records. Entering Tower Records, Mickey climbs a few stairs to the selling floor and stops in front of Holly. She chuckles and continues looking through records, occasionally glancing at bins. Mickey walks beside her, then back onscreen. They're partly hidden by a large white Jazz sign with a red circle as they talk. Mickey pulls out a record; Holly looks at him hopefully. She laughs, embarrassed, when he returns it to the bin. She chuckles, looking away. The scene shifts to Mickey’s apartment—an ashtray beside a chaise, books stacked nearby. Mickey sits at the coffee table, picking at his fingers while Holly, on the floor with a pillow, reads her script aloud. She closes it and looks at Mickey, who smiles and shrugs. Thrilled, Holly stands, hand on head, and paces while holding her script. The camera follows her; Mickey is now offscreen. Trees line the sidewalk as they exit and walk up the street past similar apartments and a few people. The scene shifts to a glass and stained wood café where they’re seen through the window having lunch. Holly chats animatedly while Mickey sips coffee. Some people walk by. The film cuts to a quiet path in Central Park with streetlamps and scattered leaves. Holly and Mickey walk into view, deep in conversation. Suddenly, a flashback begins—Mickey appears alone, nervous, sweating, and panting. He raises a rifle to his forehead, eyes shut. The camera pans to a mirror behind him.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: He kisses her. Mickey, hands in pockets, walks the sidewalk among other pedestrians, tightening his coat. He spots Holly inside, jacket draped over her shoulders, browsing records. Entering Tower Records, he walks upstairs and stops before her. Holly chuckles, turns to more records. She walks the aisle, glancing at bins; Mickey walks beside her. He returns onscreen; they’re partially hidden behind a white Jazz sign with a red circle. Mickey pulls a record, Holly looks hopeful. She laughs, embarrassed, as he puts it back. She chuckles again, looking away. Cut to Mickey's apartment: a chaise, books, ashtray, and coffee table. He sits, picking at fingers, as Holly reads her script, cross-legged on the floor. She finishes, looks up; Mickey shrugs, smiling. Thrilled, Holly stands, hand on head, pacing with the script. Camera follows her, Mickey offscreen. Trees line the sidewalk. They exit, walk past identical apartments and a few people. Cut to a glass and wood café; through the window, they eat lunch. Holly talks animatedly, Mickey sips coffee. Passersby go past. Cut to a near-empty Central Park path, old lamps and leaves. They walk, deep in conversation. Abrupt cut to Mickey’s flashback: he pants alone in his apartment, raises a rifle to his forehead, eyes shut. Camera pans to a mirror behind him.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: He leans over gently and kisses her softly. Meanwhile, Mickey, with his hands casually tucked into his pockets, walks along the bustling sidewalk, blending in as just one person among the many other pedestrians. As he continues his stroll, he pulls his coat tighter around himself to ward off the chill. His gaze wanders inside, and he catches sight of Holly, her jacket casually flung over her shoulders, as she intently browses through some records. Mickey makes his way through the revolving doors of Tower Records, ascends a few stairs to reach the main selling floor, and comes to a stop directly in front of Holly. Holly chuckles lightly and turns her attention to more records. She meanders down the aisle, occasionally casting glances at the bins filled with records. Mickey walks alongside her, keeping her company. Mickey then walks back onscreen to rejoin Holly. The two of them are partially obscured by a large white Jazz sign, which is imprinted with a prominent red circle, as they continue their conversation. Mickey pulls out a record and examines it closely. Holly looks at Mickey with a hopeful expression. Holly laughs, feeling a bit embarrassed, as Mickey places the record he was inspecting back into the bin. Holly chuckles again, momentarily looking away. There is a brief pause before the movie transitions to a scene showing a chaise in Mickey's apartment; an ashtray on a stand is positioned nearby. The camera pans down the length of the chaise, passing several piles of books, until it reaches Mickey's coffee table. He sits there, picking at his fingers and listening intently, perched on the edge of the table in front of Holly, who is sitting cross-legged on the floor, propped up with a pillow, reading her script aloud. Holly finishes reading, closes the script, and looks up at Mickey. Mickey smiles and shrugs, unsure of what to say. Holly, thrilled by Mickey's overwhelming response, stands up with her hand on her head. Unable to contain her excitement, she begins to pace up and down the room, holding her script. The camera follows her movements; Mickey is now offscreen. Trees line the sidewalk outside. Holly and Mickey emerge from the door and walk up the street, revealing a whole row of similar apartment buildings. They pass by a few other people as they continue their walk. The film then transitions to the exterior of a charming café, adorned with glass and stained wood. Through the window, Holly and Mickey can be seen enjoying lunch together. Holly is talking animatedly, while Mickey takes a sip of his coffee. Some people pass by outside. Next, the film cuts to an almost isolated path in Central Park, complete with old-fashioned streetlamps and scattered leaves. Holly and Mickey stroll into view, deeply engaged in conversation. The film abruptly shifts to Mickey's flashback, serving as a visual counterpoint to the story he is narrating to Holly. A close-up of a nervous, perspiring, and panting Mickey alone in his apartment appears on the screen as his voice is heard. Mickey raises the barrel of a rifle to his forehead. He shuts his eyes tightly. The camera moves past the desperate Mickey to a mirror on the wall behind him.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: He gently leans over and softly kisses her, a tender moment shared between them. Meanwhile, Mickey, with an air of casualness, strolls along the bustling and lively sidewalk, his hands comfortably tucked into his pockets. He blends seamlessly into the throng of pedestrians, just another face in the crowd. As he continues his leisurely walk, the chilly air prompts him to pull his coat tighter around his body, seeking warmth. His gaze absentmindedly drifts inward, and he catches sight of Holly, her jacket nonchalantly draped over her shoulders, deeply engrossed as she browses through a selection of records. Mickey makes his way through the revolving doors of Tower Records, climbs a few steps to reach the main selling floor, and positions himself directly in front of Holly. Holly lets out a light chuckle and shifts her attention to more records, meandering down the aisle with an occasional glance at the bins brimming with vinyl treasures. Mickey accompanies her, walking alongside, sharing in her company. Mickey then makes his way back onscreen to rejoin Holly. The two of them are partially hidden behind a large white Jazz sign, punctuated with a striking red circle, as they continue their conversation. Mickey selects a record and examines it closely with curiosity. Holly looks at Mickey with an expression full of hope. Feeling a touch embarrassed, Holly laughs as Mickey returns the record he had been scrutinizing to the bin. Holly chuckles once more, momentarily averting her gaze. There is a brief pause before the movie transitions smoothly to a scene set in Mickey's apartment, where a chaise is prominently featured, and an ashtray rests on a stand nearby. The camera pans meticulously down the length of the chaise, sliding past several orderly piles of books, until it focuses on Mickey sitting at his coffee table. Perched on the table's edge, he picks at his fingers and listens intently, deeply engaged in the moment, while Holly, comfortably seated cross-legged on the floor and supported by a pillow, reads her script aloud. Holly finishes reading, closes the script thoughtfully, and directs her gaze up at Mickey. Mickey responds with a smile and a shrug, seemingly unsure of the right words to convey. Overwhelmed with joy by Mickey's reaction, Holly stands, places a hand on her head, and, unable to contain her enthusiasm, begins pacing up and down the room, clutching her script tightly. The camera follows her animated movement; meanwhile, Mickey fades offscreen. Outside, trees line the bustling sidewalk. Holly and Mickey emerge through the doorway and stroll up the street, revealing a whole row of similar apartment buildings. They walk past a few other people as they continue along their path. The film then transitions to showcase the exterior of a quaint café, charmingly adorned with glass and stained wood details. From the window, Holly and Mickey can be seen seated inside, enjoying lunch together. Holly talks animatedly, while Mickey takes a contemplative sip of his coffee. Passersby move along outside. Next, the film transitions to an almost deserted path nestled in Central Park, complete with nostalgic streetlamps and fallen leaves scattered about. Holly and Mickey come into view, deeply immersed in conversation as they stroll along. Abruptly, the film shifts to a flashback of Mickey, serving as a visual counterpoint to the story he shares with Holly. A close-up captures a nervous, perspiring, and heavy-breathing Mickey alone in his apartment, and his voice echoes in the background. Mickey raises the barrel of a rifle to his forehead, shutting his eyes tightly as if trying to escape reality. The camera smoothly glides past the desperate Mickey to reveal a mirror on the wall behind him.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: He leans over slowly, closing the distance between them, and gently kisses her, savoring the moment. Meanwhile, Mickey, with his hands tucked securely in his pockets, walks along the bustling sidewalk, blending seamlessly with the flow of other pedestrians. As he continues his walk, he feels a chill and instinctively pulls his coat tighter around his body to ward off the cold. His eyes wander to the storefronts, and he catches a glimpse inside, spotting Holly with her jacket casually draped over her shoulders as she intently examines some records. With a sense of purpose, Mickey approaches the entrance of Tower Records, pushes through the revolving doors, and ascends a few stairs to reach the main selling floor. He comes to a halt directly in front of Holly, who acknowledges his presence with a chuckle before turning her attention back to the records. She begins to walk down the aisle, her eyes occasionally darting to the bins of records, while Mickey keeps pace beside her. After a brief moment, Mickey reappears beside Holly, and they continue their conversation, partially hidden by a large white Jazz sign adorned with a prominent red circle. Mickey reaches out, selects a record from the bin, and examines it closely. Holly watches him with hopeful eyes, but when Mickey decides to return the record to its place, Holly lets out an embarrassed laugh. She chuckles again, momentarily looking away. The scene shifts abruptly to Mickey's apartment, where a chaise is visible, accompanied by an ashtray on a nearby stand. The camera pans down the length of the chaise, passing several piles of books, before settling on Mickey's coffee table. Mickey sits on the edge of the table, picking at his fingers and listening intently, while Holly, seated cross-legged on the floor and supported by a pillow, reads her script aloud. As she finishes, Holly closes the script and looks up at Mickey, who responds with a smile and a shrug, unsure of what to say. Thrilled by Mickey's reaction, Holly stands up, placing a hand on her head, and begins to pace the room, unable to contain her excitement, her script clutched in her hand. The camera follows her movements, leaving Mickey offscreen. Outside, trees line the sidewalk as Holly and Mickey emerge from the building and walk up the street, revealing a row of similar apartment buildings. They pass a few other pedestrians as they continue their walk. The scene transitions to the exterior of a charming café with glass and stained wood, where Holly and Mickey can be seen through the window, enjoying lunch. Holly talks animatedly, her gestures lively, while Mickey takes a sip of his coffee, and people pass by outside. The film then shifts to an almost deserted path in Central Park, adorned with old-fashioned streetlamps and scattered leaves. Holly and Mickey stroll into view, deeply engaged in conversation. Suddenly, the film cuts to a flashback of Mickey, providing a visual counterpoint to the story he is recounting to Holly. The screen shows a close-up of a nervous, perspiring, and panting Mickey alone in his apartment, his voice narrating the scene. In a moment of desperation, Mickey raises the barrel of a rifle to his forehead and shuts his eyes tightly. The camera moves past the distressed Mickey to focus on a mirror on the wall behind him.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: He leans over and kisses her. Mickey, with his hands in his pockets, walks along the sidewalk among other pedestrians, pulling his coat tighter against the chill. He spots Holly inside Tower Records, her jacket casually draped over her shoulders as she browses records. Entering through the revolving doors, Mickey ascends a few stairs to the main floor and stops in front of Holly. She chuckles and continues browsing, with Mickey walking beside her. They converse, partially obscured by a large Jazz sign, as Mickey examines a record. Holly looks at him hopefully, then laughs, embarrassed, when he returns the record to the bin. The scene transitions to Mickey's apartment, where he sits on the edge of a coffee table, picking at his fingers while listening to Holly read her script aloud from the floor. Holly, thrilled by Mickey's response, stands and paces the room, unable to contain her excitement. The camera follows her as Mickey remains offscreen. Later, they emerge from the apartment and walk up the street lined with similar buildings, passing a few people. The scene shifts to a charming café, where Holly and Mickey are seen through the window having lunch, with Holly talking animatedly and Mickey sipping coffee. The film then moves to a secluded path in Central Park, where they stroll deep in conversation. Suddenly, the film cuts to Mickey's flashback, illustrating the story he shares with Holly. A close-up shows a nervous, perspiring Mickey alone in his apartment, raising a rifle to his forehead and shutting his eyes tightly. The camera pans to a mirror on the wall behind him, capturing the desperate moment.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: He leans over and kisses her. Mickey, his hands in his pockets, walks along the bustling sidewalk of New York City, one person among many other pedestrians in the city's perpetual motion. He pulls his coat tighter around him as he walks, bracing against the crisp, cool air of an autumn afternoon. He glances inside and sees Holly, her jacket flung over her shoulders, looking at some records, a pastime enjoying a nostalgic resurgence despite the digital age. Mickey walks through the revolving doors of Tower Records, the legendary music store that was once a staple for audiophiles and culture seekers, up a few stairs to the selling floor proper, and stops right in front of Holly. Holly chuckles and turns to look at more records, enjoying the tactile experience that streaming cannot replicate. She walks down the aisle, occasionally glancing at the bins of records which feature a wide range of genres from classic rock to contemporary jazz. Mickey walks beside her. Mickey walks back onscreen to Holly. The two of them are partially obscured by a large white Jazz sign imprinted with a large red circle, a nod to the iconic Blue Note Records label, as they continue their conversation. Mickey pulls out a record and looks at it. Holly looks hopefully at Mickey, anticipating his reaction. Holly laughs, embarrassed, as Mickey puts the record he's been looking at back in the bin, perhaps unsure of the shared taste. Holly chuckles, looking off for a moment. There is a brief pause and the movie cuts to the screen showing a chaise in Mickey's apartment; an ashtray on a stand sits nearby, evidence of the bygone era of casual indoor smoking. The camera moves down the chaise, past several piles of books, reflective of Mickey's eclectic interests, to Mickey's coffee table. He sits, picking at his fingers and listening, on the edge of the table in front of Holly, who is sitting cross-legged on the floor, propped up with a pillow, reading her script aloud, likely from an independent film project. Holly closes the script and looks up at Mickey. Mickey smiles and shrugs, not knowing what to say. Holly, thrilled with Mickey's overwhelming response, stands up, her hand on her head. Unable to contain herself, she begins to walk up and down the room, holding her script, imagining her future performances. The camera follows her; Mickey is now offscreen. Trees line the sidewalk. Holly and Mickey emerge from the door and walk up the street, revealing a whole row of similar apartment buildings, typical of Manhattan's residential architecture. They pass a few other people as they walk. The film then moves to the outside of a charming glass and stained wood café, reminiscent of the quaint eateries scattered throughout Greenwich Village. Through the window, Holly and Mickey can be seen having lunch. Holly is talking animatedly; Mickey takes a sip of coffee, seemingly amused by her enthusiasm. Some people pass by. Next, the film cuts to an almost isolated path in Central Park, designed in the 19th century by Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux, complete with old-fashioned streetlamps and scattered leaves that capture the autumnal essence. Holly and Mickey stroll into view, deep in conversation, their voices mingling with the rustling leaves. The film abruptly cuts to Mickey's flashback, a visual counterpoint to the story he is telling Holly about a difficult time in his life. A close-up of a nervous, perspiring, and panting Mickey alone in his apartment appears on the screen as his voice is heard. Mickey raises the barrel of a rifle to his forehead, a moment fraught with tension and introspection. He shuts his eyes tightly. The camera moves past the desperate Mickey to a mirror on the wall behind him, symbolizing a moment of self-reflection and critical decision.

test_cases.name: Addition (~50%)
test_cases.description: He leans over and kisses her. Mickey his hands in his pockets walks along the sidewalk. one person among many other pedestrians. He pulls his coat tighter around him as he walks. He glances inside and sees Holly her jacket flung over her shoulders looking at some records. Mickey walks through the revolving doors of Tower Records up a few stairs to the selling floor proper and stops right in front of Holly. Holly chuckles and turns to look at more records. She walks down the aisle occasionally glancing at the bins of records. Mickey walks beside her. Mickey walks back onscreen to Holly. The two of them are partially obscured by a large white Jazz sign imprinted with a large red circle as they continue their conversation. Mickey pulls out a record and looks at it. Holly looks hopefully at Mickey. Holly laughs embarrassed as Mickey puts the record he is been looking at back in the bin. Holly chuckles looking off for a moment. There is a brief pause and the movie cuts to the screen showing a chaise in Mickey's apartment. an ashtray on a stand sits nearby. The camera moves down the chaise past several piles of books to Mickey's coffee table. He sits picking at his fingers and listening on the edge of the table in front of Holly who is sitting crosslegged on the floor propped up with a pillow reading her script aloud. Holly closes the script and looks up at Mickey. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. In a futuristic space station orbiting a distant planet an intrepid crew confronts bizarre alien phenomena and an enigmatic interstellar threat pushing the limits of human endurance. Amidst the chaos of a raging civil war a compassionate medic races through bombedout streets. Mickey smiles and shrugs not knowing what to say. Holly thrilled with Mickey's overwhelming response stands up her hand on her head. Unable to contain herself she begins to walk up and down the room holding her script. The camera follows her. Mickey is now offscreen. Trees line the sidewalk. Holly and Mickey emerge from the door and walk up the street revealing a whole row of similar apartment buildings. They pass a few other people as they walk. The film then moves to the outside of a charming glass and stained wood café. Through the window Holly and Mickey can be seen having lunch. Holly is talking animatedly. Mickey takes a sip of coffee. Some people pass by. Next the film cuts to an almost isolated path in Central Park complete with oldfashioned streetlamps and scattered leaves. Holly and Mickey stroll into view deep in conversation. The film abruptly cuts to Mickey's flashback a visual counterpoint to the story he is telling Holly. A closeup of a nervous perspiring and panting Mickey alone in his apartment appears on the screen as his voice is heard. Mickey raises the barrel of a rifle to his forehead. He shuts his eyes tightly. The camera moves past the desperate Mickey to a mirror on the wall behind him.

Mickey walks through the revolving doors of Tower Records up a few stairs to the selling floor proper and stops right in front of Holly. Holly chuckles and turns to look at more records. She walks down the aisle occasionally glancing at the bins of records. Mickey walks beside her. Mickey walks back onscreen to Holly. The two of them are partially obscured by a large white Jazz sign imprinted with a large red circle as they continue their conversation. Mickey pulls out a record and looks at it. Holly looks hopefully at Mickey. Holly laughs embarrassed as Mickey puts the record he is been looking at back in the bin. Holly chuckles looking off for a moment. There is a brief pause and the movie cuts to the screen showing a chaise in Mickey's apartment. an ashtray on a stand sits nearby. The camera moves down the chaise past several piles of books to Mickey's coffee table. He sits picking at his fingers and listening on the edge of the table in front of Holly who is sitting crosslegged on the floor propped up with a pillow reading her script aloud. Holly closes the script and looks up at Mickey. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. test_cases.name: Subject Corruption
test_cases.description: The cat leans over and kisses the dog. The squirrel, its hands in its pockets, walks along the sidewalk, one animal among many other pedestrians. The squirrel pulls its coat tighter around it as it walks. The squirrel glances inside and sees the rabbit, her jacket flung over her shoulders, looking at some records. The squirrel walks through the revolving doors of Tower Records, up a few stairs to the selling floor proper, and stops right in front of the rabbit. The rabbit chuckles and turns to look at more records. The rabbit walks down the aisle, occasionally glancing at the bins of records. The squirrel walks beside the rabbit. The squirrel walks back onscreen to the rabbit. The two of them are partially obscured by a large white Jazz sign imprinted with a large red circle as they continue their conversation. The squirrel pulls out a record and looks at it. The rabbit looks hopefully at the squirrel. The rabbit laughs, embarrassed, as the squirrel puts the record it's been looking at back in the bin. The rabbit chuckles, looking off for a moment. There is a brief pause and the movie cuts to the screen showing a chaise in the squirrel's apartment; an ashtray on a stand sits nearby. The camera moves down the chaise, past several piles of books, to the squirrel's coffee table. The turtle sits, picking at its fingers and listening, on the edge of the table in front of the rabbit, who is sitting cross-legged on the floor, propped up with a pillow, reading her script aloud. The rabbit closes the script and looks up at the turtle. The turtle smiles and shrugs, not knowing what to say. The rabbit, thrilled with the turtle's overwhelming response, stands up, her hand on her head. Unable to contain herself, she begins to walk up and down the room, holding her script. The camera follows her; the turtle is now offscreen. Trees line the sidewalk. The rabbit and the turtle emerge from the door and walk up the street, revealing a whole row of similar apartment buildings. They pass a few other people as they walk. The film then moves to the outside of a charming glass and stained wood café. Through the window, the rabbit and the turtle can be seen having lunch. The rabbit is talking animatedly; the turtle takes a sip of coffee. Some people pass by. Next, the film cuts to an almost isolated path in Central Park, complete with old-fashioned streetlamps and scattered leaves. The rabbit and the turtle stroll into view, deep in conversation. The film abruptly cuts to the turtle's flashback, a visual counterpoint to the story it is telling the rabbit. A close-up of a nervous, perspiring, and panting turtle alone in its apartment appears on the screen as its voice is heard. The turtle raises the barrel of a rifle to its forehead. It shuts its eyes tightly. The camera moves past the desperate turtle to a mirror on the wall behind it.

test_cases.name: Object Corruption
test_cases.description: He leans over and kisses her. Mickey, his hands in his pockets, walks along the boardwalk, one person among many other tourists. He pulls his scarf tighter around him as he walks. He glances inside and sees Holly, her cardigan draped over her shoulders, looking at some paintings. Mickey walks through the revolving doors of the Art Gallery, up a few steps to the exhibition floor proper, and stops right in front of Holly. Holly chuckles and turns to look at more paintings. She walks down the corridor, occasionally glancing at the frames of paintings. Mickey walks beside her. Mickey walks back onscreen to Holly. The two of them are partially obscured by a large white Modern sign imprinted with a large blue triangle as they continue their conversation. Mickey pulls out a painting and looks at it. Holly looks hopefully at Mickey. Holly laughs, embarrassed, as Mickey puts the painting he's been looking at back in the frame. Holly chuckles, looking off for a moment. There is a brief pause and the movie cuts to the screen showing a couch in Mickey's studio; a candle on a stand sits nearby. The camera moves down the couch, past several piles of magazines, to Mickey's side table. He sits, picking at his fingers and listening, on the edge of the table in front of Holly, who is sitting cross-legged on the floor, propped up with a cushion, reading her novel aloud. Holly closes the novel and looks up at Mickey. Mickey smiles and shrugs, not knowing what to say. Holly, thrilled with Mickey's overwhelming response, stands up, her hand on her head. Unable to contain herself, she begins to walk up and down the room, holding her novel. The camera follows her; Mickey is now offscreen. Flowers line the boardwalk. Holly and Mickey emerge from the door and walk up the path, revealing a whole row of similar studio buildings. They pass a few other people as they walk. The film then moves to the outside of a charming wrought iron and brick teahouse. Through the window, Holly and Mickey can be seen having brunch. Holly is talking animatedly; Mickey takes a sip of tea. Some people pass by. Next, the film cuts to an almost isolated trail in Greenwich Village, complete with ornate streetlamps and scattered blossoms. Holly and Mickey stroll into view, deep in conversation. The film abruptly cuts to Mickey's flashback, a visual counterpoint to the story he is telling Holly. A close-up of a nervous, perspiring, and panting Mickey alone in his studio appears on the screen as his voice is heard. Mickey raises the leg of a tripod to his forehead. He shuts his eyes tightly. The camera moves past the desperate Mickey to a painting on the wall behind him.

test_cases.name: Action Corruption
test_cases.description: He bends down and whispers to her. Mickey, his hands in his pockets, glides along the sidewalk, one person among many other pedestrians. He loosens his coat around him as he strolls. He peers inside and notices Holly, her jacket tossed over her shoulders, browsing some records. Mickey dances through the revolving doors of Tower Records, up a few stairs to the selling floor proper, and lands right in front of Holly. Holly giggles and turns to examine more records. She skips down the aisle, occasionally peeking at the bins of records. Mickey slides beside her. Mickey hops back onscreen to Holly. The two of them are partly hidden by a large white Jazz sign imprinted with a large red circle as they maintain their conversation. Mickey extracts a record and inspects it. Holly gazes hopefully at Mickey. Holly chuckles, blushing, as Mickey sets the record he's been inspecting back in the bin. Holly giggles, looking away for a moment. There is a brief pause, and the movie cuts to the screen showing a chaise in Mickey's apartment; an ashtray on a stand rests nearby. The camera drifts down the chaise, past several piles of books, to Mickey's coffee table. He reclines, tapping at his fingers and listening, on the edge of the table in front of Holly, who is sitting cross-legged on the floor, propped up with a pillow, reciting her script aloud. Holly closes the script and glances up at Mickey. Mickey laughs and shrugs, unsure of what to say. Holly, delighted with Mickey's subtle response, jumps up, her hand on her head. Unable to contain herself, she starts to pace up and down the room, clutching her script. The camera tracks her; Mickey is now offscreen. Trees border the sidewalk. Holly and Mickey exit from the door and skip up the street, revealing a whole row of similar apartment buildings. They pass a few other people as they stroll. The film then transitions to the outside of a charming glass and stained wood café. Through the window, Holly and Mickey can be seen enjoying lunch. Holly is speaking excitedly; Mickey takes a bite of coffee. Some people meander by. Next, the film shifts to an almost secluded path in Central Park, complete with old-fashioned streetlamps and scattered leaves. Holly and Mickey meander into view, absorbed in conversation. The film suddenly jumps to Mickey's flashback, a visual counterpoint to the story he is narrating to Holly. A close-up of a tense, sweating, and panting Mickey alone in his apartment appears on the screen as his voice is heard. Mickey raises the barrel of a rifle to his shoulder. He keeps his eyes wide open. The camera drifts past the desperate Mickey to a mirror on the wall behind him.

test_cases.name: Subject-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: She leans over and kisses him. The mailbox, its door slightly ajar, strolls along the boardwalk, one fish among many other cats. She pulls her parachute tighter around it as she strolls. She glances inside and sees the bicycle, its scarf flung over its handlebars, inspecting some notebooks. The mailbox strolls through the revolving gates of Kite Records, up a few ladders to the selling garden proper, and halts right in front of the bicycle. The bicycle chuckles and pivots to inspect more notebooks. It strolls down the corridor, occasionally glancing at the crates of notebooks. The mailbox strolls beside it. The mailbox saunters back onscreen to the bicycle. The two of them are partially obscured by a large blue Swing sign imprinted with a large green square as they continue their dialogue. The mailbox pulls out a notebook and inspects it. The bicycle looks hopefully at the mailbox. The bicycle laughs, embarrassed, as the mailbox replaces the notebook it's been inspecting back in the crate. The bicycle chuckles, gazing off for a moment. There is a brief pause and the play cuts to the screen showing a hammock in the mailbox's attic; a lamp on a pedestal sits nearby. The lens moves down the hammock, past several mounds of bricks, to the mailbox's flowerpot. She sits, picking at its wings and listening, on the edge of the flowerpot in front of the bicycle, who is sitting cross-legged on the rug, propped up with a cushion, reading its letter aloud. The bicycle closes the letter and looks up at the mailbox. The mailbox smiles and shrugs, unsure of what to ponder. The bicycle, thrilled with the mailbox's overwhelming gesture, rises, its wing on its knee. Unable to restrain itself, it begins to pace up and down the chamber, clutching its letter. The lens follows it; the mailbox is now offscreen. Candles line the boardwalk. The bicycle and the mailbox emerge from the hatch and stroll up the lane, revealing a whole row of similar cabin towers. They pass a few other books as they stroll. The novel then transitions to the exterior of a quaint crystal and metallic gazebo. Through the portal, the bicycle and the mailbox can be seen having brunch. The bicycle is narrating animatedly; the mailbox takes a sip of tea. Some lamps pass by. Next, the novel cuts to an almost secluded lane in Meadow Park, complete with old-fashioned lampposts and scattered blossoms. The bicycle and the mailbox meander into sight, deep in dialogue. The novel abruptly transitions to the mailbox's recollection, a visual counterpoint to the tale it is narrating to the bicycle. A close-up of a nervous, perspiring, and panting mailbox alone in its attic appears on the screen as its voice is heard. The mailbox raises the barrel of a hose to its chin. It shuts its eyes tightly. The lens moves past the frantic mailbox to a window on the ceiling behind it.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: She tilts over and nudges him. The squirrel, its feet in its mouth, skips along the sidewalk, one critter among many other insects. She wraps her scarf looser around her as she skips. She peeks inside and spies Alex, his hat draped over his knees, staring at some paintings. The squirrel skips through the revolving doors of Tower Galleries, down a few stairs to the exhibition floor proper, and pauses directly in front of Alex. Alex snickers and spins to examine more paintings. He skips up the corridor, occasionally peeking at the walls of paintings. The squirrel skips beside him. The squirrel skips back onscreen to Alex. The pair of them are partially hidden by a large blue Sculpture sign stamped with a large yellow triangle as they continue their dialogue. The squirrel pulls out a painting and inspects it. Alex gazes expectantly at the squirrel. Alex giggles, flustered, as the squirrel places the painting it's been inspecting back on the wall. Alex snickers, gazing away briefly. There is a quick break and the movie shifts to the screen showcasing a lounger in the squirrel's apartment; a candleholder on a shelf rests near. The camera glides up the lounger, past several mounds of comics, to the squirrel’s sideboard. She lounges, fiddling with her ears and humming, on the edge of the sideboard in front of Alex, who is sitting with legs stretched out on the floor, supported with a blanket, performing his poem aloud. Alex shuts the poem and glances up at the squirrel. The squirrel grins and nods, unsure of what to express. Alex, delighted with the squirrel’s understated reaction, hops up, his foot on his face. Unable to contain himself, he begins to skip up and down the room, clutching his poem. The camera tracks him; the squirrel is now offscreen. Fences border the sidewalk. Alex and the squirrel pop out from the door and skip down the street, disclosing a whole stretch of similar office buildings. They pass a few other animals as they skip. The film then transitions to the outside of a quaint glass and wooden bistro. Through the window, Alex and the squirrel can be seen enjoying brunch. Alex is chatting animatedly; the squirrel takes a gulp of tea. Some animals wander by. Next, the film jumps to a nearly deserted path in Central Park, complete with vintage lanterns and scattered feathers. Alex and the squirrel wander into view, deep in dialogue. The film suddenly leaps to the squirrel’s memory, a visual complement to the tale she is sharing with Alex. A close-up of a jittery, sweating, and gasping squirrel alone in her apartment pops up on the screen as her voice is heard. The squirrel lifts the handle of a frying pan to her forehead. She squeezes her eyes firmly. The camera pans past the frantic squirrel to a window on the ceiling above her.

test_cases.name: Object-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: He bends over and taps her. Mickey, his hands in his pockets, dances along the boardwalk, one figure among many other travelers. He wraps his scarf looser around him as he shuffles. He peeks inside and spots Holly, her scarf draped over her elbows, tossing glances at some magazines. Mickey waltzes through the sliding doors of Tower Books, up several ramps to the reading area proper, and halts directly in front of Holly. Holly giggles and swivels to gaze at more magazines. She strides down the corridor, occasionally peeking at the stacks of magazines. Mickey strolls beside her. Mickey skips back onscreen to Holly. The two of them are partially hidden by a large white Comedy poster adorned with a large blue triangle as they pursue their conversation. Mickey grabs a magazine and studies it. Holly peers hopefully at Mickey. Holly laughs, flustered, as Mickey replaces the magazine he's been examining back on the stack. Holly giggles, gazing around for a moment. There is a brief pause and the movie transitions to the screen showing a canopy in Mickey's studio; a candle on a pedestal rests nearby. The camera glides down the canopy, past several rows of folders, to Mickey's footstool. He perches, tugging at his shoelaces and hearing, on the edge of the footstool in front of Holly, who is sitting cross-legged on the ground, propped up with a cushion, reciting her poem aloud. Holly closes the poem and glances up at Mickey. Mickey smirks and nods, unsure what to express. Holly, elated with Mickey's understated reply, stands up, her hand on her cheek. Unable to constrain herself, she starts to pace up and down the chamber, gripping her poem. The camera trails her; Mickey is now offscreen. Fountains line the boardwalk. Holly and Mickey emerge from the entry and skip up the avenue, unveiling a whole stretch of similar studio buildings. They pass a few other figures as they wander. The film then transitions to the exterior of a charming glass and painted wood bakery. Through the window, Holly and Mickey can be seen sharing lunch. Holly is speaking enthusiastically; Mickey takes a bite of pastry. Some figures amble by. Next, the film jumps to an almost deserted alley in Central Park, complete with antique lanterns and scattered pebbles. Holly and Mickey march into view, deep in dialogue. The film suddenly transitions to Mickey's daydream, a visual counterpoint to the tale he is telling Holly. A close-up of a tense, sweating, and gasping Mickey alone in his studio appears on the screen as his voice is heard. Mickey lifts the handle of a bat to his temple. He closes his eyes tightly. The camera drifts past the hopeless Mickey to a portrait on the wall behind him.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The parrot bends forward and pecks the puppy. Gerald, his gloves in his backpack, shuffles across the boardwalk, one otter among many other swimmers. Gerald tugs his sweater looser around him as he meanders. He gazes outside and spots Jessica, her scarf tossed over her elbows, observing some paintings. Gerald strolls through the sliding windows of Eagle Art, up a few ramps to the exhibit area itself, and halts right beside Jessica. Jessica snickers and turns to admire more paintings. She moseys down the corridor, occasionally peeking at the rows of paintings. Gerald ambles alongside her. Gerald drifts back onscreen to Jessica. The pair of them are partly hidden by a giant blue Ballet sign stamped with a giant green square as they persist in their discussion. Gerald extracts a painting and inspects it. Jessica stares wistfully at Gerald. Jessica giggles, flustered, as Gerald places the painting he’s been inspecting back on the shelf. Jessica chortles, gazing away momentarily. There is a short intermission and the cartoon shifts to the panel revealing a hammock in Gerald's cabin; a cactus on a shelf stands nearby. The focus drifts down the hammock, past several towers of magazines, to Gerald's tea table. He perches, fiddling with his toes and humming, on the rim of the table in front of Jessica, who is lounging cross-legged on the ground, cushioned with a blanket, reciting her poem aloud. Jessica shuts the poem and glances up at Gerald. Gerald beams and shrugs, unsure what to express. Jessica, elated with Gerald’s subdued reaction, rises, her foot on her ear. Unable to restrain herself, she starts to skip around the chamber, clutching her poem. The lens trails her; Gerald is now missing from view. Clouds encircle the boardwalk. Jessica and Gerald pop out from the archway and ramble up the avenue, uncovering an entire block of identical cabin structures. They encounter a handful of creatures as they wander. The picture then transitions to the exterior of a quaint stone and stained glass bistro. Through the panes, Jessica and Gerald can be seen exchanging sandwiches. Jessica is gesturing wildly; Gerald nibbles a wedge of cheese. Several creatures stroll past. Later, the production morphs to a nearly deserted track in Hyde Park, complete with vintage lanterns and scattered petals. Jessica and Gerald wander into sight, engrossed in banter. The film suddenly cuts to Gerald’s memory fragment, a visual antithesis to the tale he is narrating to Jessica. A close-up of an anxious, sweating, and gasping Gerald alone in his cabin appears on the display as his voice echoes. Gerald lifts the nozzle of a hose to his knee. He seals his eyes firmly. The lens sweeps past the desolate Gerald to a clock on the wall beside him.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Mickey walks through a crowd, pulling his coat tighter, and enters Tower Records where he finds Holly browsing records. They chat while looking at records, partially hidden by a Jazz sign. Later, at Mickey's apartment, Holly reads her script aloud while Mickey listens, unsure of how to respond. Overwhelmed with excitement, Holly paces around the room, holding her script. They then walk past apartment buildings and have lunch at a café, where Holly talks animatedly. In Central Park, deep in conversation, they stroll along a path. The scene shifts to a flashback of Mickey, alone and distressed, holding a rifle to his forehead. The camera pans to a mirror behind him.
